awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Conference on Auctions, Firm Behavior, and Policy
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a collaborative project between the University of Oklahoma and Colby College. The award funds conferences that will be held in Oklahoma and Maine. The goal of the conferences is to develop new research collaborations for US scholars, including international collaborations. The conferences will focus on auction economics and network economics. The conferences will stimulate new ideas in these areas of economics. Speakers who adopt different methodological approaches will be invited. The conference organizers will target researchers from other EPSCoR states for participation, including researchers from institutions in Kansas, Arkansas, Louisiana, New Hampshire, and Vermont. Students will also participate and present their research in student-focused sessions.

Specific topics include (i) Structural econometrics of auctions and networks; (2) The use of lab and field experiments in the study of auctions and bargaining; (3) Applications of auctions to a range of settings, including government procurement, charity auctions, environmental auctions, and multi-unit auctions; modeling discrete strategic actions, especially entry behavior in auctions; (5) Public policy issues in auction design.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: PRESIDENT AND TRUSTEES OF COLBY COLLEGE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Conferences on Auctions, Firm Behavior, and Policy held at Colby College (June 2023) and the University of Oklahoma (June 2024) provided a vibrant platform for advancing understanding in the fields of auctions, network analysis, and public policy. These events brought together researchers, students, and practitioners to share cutting-edge insights and foster collaboration.

Intellectual Merit: The conferences showcased cutting edge research on auctions and their applications in diverse areas, including government procurement focusing on firm behavior as well as the housing markets and the environment. Discussions also covered auction formats such as first-price, multi-unit, charity, and all-pay auctions, alongside network and firm behavior studies.

Both events emphasized innovative, work-in-progress research. Presenters benefited from detailed feedback from discussants and attendees, allowing them to refine and enhance their studies. Attendees, in turn, gained exposure to new methodologies and approaches, fostering a deeper understanding of complex economic mechanisms. This intellectual exchange has contributed to the advancement of knowledge in the field, supporting further research and publication in leading economic journals.

Broader Impacts: The conferences achieved broad representation, convening participants from across the U.S., including EPSCoR states such as Maine, Oklahoma, and Vermont. The mix of early-career scholars, including Ph.D. students and recent graduates, with seasoned academics ensured a dynamic exchange of ideas.

Efforts to disseminate the results were extensive. A call for papers and announcements about the conferences reached a wide audience through academic networks, social media, and listservs. The conference websites, featuring programs and access to presented papers, continue to serve as valuable resources for the academic community.

The broader impacts extended beyond academia. The research presented has real-world applications, including improving government procurement processes, supporting small businesses, and addressing environmental and social challenges through innovative auction designs and policies. Additionally, the events fostered professional development by offering young researchers opportunities to present their work, receive constructive feedback, and network with established scholars in the field.


Last Modified: 03/11/2025
Modified by: Timothy Hubbard
